text.p: The following are the main stories from Thursday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel says Turkey will not become member of the European Union in the foreseeable future.
- Krupp KFHG.F and Thyssen agree to found joint steel company.
- Atomic energy industry ready to compromise over problem of waste disposal.
- Krupp and Thyssen company will bring savings of 550 million marks per year, mean the lost of 7,900 jobs.
- Association of savings banks say reform of tax system overdue.
HANDELSBLATT
- No compulsory redundancies as part of steel merger.
- Daimler-Benz plans to pay dividend again, after not doing so for 1995.
- Veba posts record results, plans New York stock exchange listing.
- German Trade Union Federation calls for employment policy agreements to be added to European Union's Maastricht Treaty.
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- Bavarian interior minister says the state will continue to repatriate Bosnian refugees.
- Row within Bavaria's Christian Social Union (CSU) between Bonn and Munich rumbles on.
- Lower oil prices help bring small drop in consumer prices for western Germany in March.
- Frankfurt court says remailing is against law but refers to European Court for final decision.
DIE WELT
- Ruling coalition puts pressure on opposition Social Democrats (SPD) to resume talks over tax reform.
- Finance Minister Theo Waigel's deliberations about further cuts in social spending provoke controversy.
- Business consultant Roland Berger says Germany is lacking eight million jobs and needs to concentrate on innovation if it is to create new jobs.
-- Bonn Newsroom +49 228 26097160
